DUAN FIRST.</br>The sun had clos'd the winter-day,</br>The Curlers quat their roaring play,</br>And hunger'd Maukin taen her way</br>To kail-yards green,</br>While faithless snaws ilk step betray</br>Whare she has been.
The Thresher's weary flingin-tree,</br>The lee-lang day had tir'd me;</br>And when the Day had clos'd his e'e,</br>Far i' the West,</br>Ben i' the Spence, right pensivelie,</br>I gaed to rest.

There, lanely, by the ingle-cheek,</br>I sat and ey'd the spewing reek,</br>That fill'd, wi' hoast-provoking smeek,</br>The auld, clay biggin;</br>And heard the restless rattons squeak</br>About the riggin.
All in this mottie, misty clime,</br>I backward mus'd on wasted time,</br>How I had spent my youthfu' prime,</br>An' done nae-thing,</br>But stringing blethers up in rhyme</br>For fools to sing.

Had I to guid advice but harket,</br>I might, by this, hae led a market,</br>Or strutted in a Bank and clarket,</br>My Cash-Account;</br>While here, half-mad, half-fed, half-farket,</br>Is a' the' amount.

I started, mutt'ring blockhead!  coof!</br>And heav'd on high my wauket loof,</br>To swear by a' yon starry roof,</br>Or some rash aith,</br>That I, henceforth, would be rhyme-proof</br>Till my last breath—

When click!  the string the snick did draw;</br>And jee!  the door gaed to the wa';</br>And by my ingle-lowe I saw,</br>Now bleezan bright,</br>A tight, outlandish Hizzie, braw,</br>Come full in sight.

Ye need na doubt, I held my whisht;</br>The infant aith, half-form'd, was crusht;</br>I glowr'd as eerie's I'd been dusht,</br>In some whild glen;</br>When sweet, like modest Worth, she blusht,</br>And stepped ben.

Green, slender, leaf-clad Holly-bought</br>Were twisted, gracefu', round her brows,</br>I took her for some SCOTTISH MUSE,</br>By that same token;</br>And come to stop those reckless vows,</br>Would soon been been broken.
A "hare-brain'd, sentimental trace"</br>Was strongly marked in her face;</br>A wildly-witty, rustic grace</br>Shone full upon her;</br>Her eye, ev'n turn'd on empty space,</br>Beam'd keen with Honor.

Down flow'd her robe, a tartan sheen,</br>Till half a leg was scrimply seen;</br>And such a leg!  my BESS, I ween,</br>Could only peer it;</br>Sae straught, sae taper, tight and clean,</br>Nane else came near it.
Her Mantle large, of greenish hue,</br>My gazing wonder chiefly drew;</br>Deep light and shades, bold-mingling, threw</br>A lustre grand;</br>And seem'd, to my astonish'd view,</br>A well-known Land.

Here, rivers in the sea were lost;</br>There, mountains to the skies were tost:</br>Here, tumbling billows mark'd the coast,</br>With surging foam;</br>There, distant shone, Art's lofty boast,</br>The lordly dome.

Here, DOON pour'd down his far-fetch'd floods;</br>There, well-fed IRVINE stately thuds:</br>Auld, hermit AIRE staw thro' his woods,</br>On to the shore;</br>And many a lesser torrent scuds,</br>With seeming roar.
Low, in a sandy valley spread,</br>An ancient BOROUGH rear'd her head;</br>Still, as in Scottish Story read,</br>She boasts a Race,</br>To ev'ry nobler virtue bred,</br>And polish'd grace.

DUAN SECOND.</br>With musing-deep, astonish'd stare,</br>I view'd the heavenly-seeming Fair;</br>A whisp'ring throb did witness bear</br>Of kindred sweet,</br>When with an elder Sister's air</br>She did me greet.
"All hail!  my own inspired Bard!</br>In me thy native Muse regard!</br>Nor longer mourn thy fate is hard,</br>Thus poorly low!</br>I come to give thee such reward,</br>As we bestow.
"Know, the great Genius of this Land,</br>Has many a light, aerial band,</br>Who, all beneath his high command,</br>Harmoniously,</br>As Arts or Arms they understand,</br>Their labors ply.
"They SCOTIA'S Race among them share;</br>Some fire the Sodger on to dare;</br>Some rouse the Patriot up to bare</br>Corruption's heart:</br>Some teach the Bard, a darling care,</br>The tuneful Art.

"'Mong swelling floods of reeking gore,</br>They ardent, kindling spirits pour;</br>Or, mid the venal Senate's roar,</br>They, sightless, stand,</br>To mend the honest Patriot-lore,</br>And grace the hand.

"Hence, FULLARTON, the brave and young;</br>Hence, DEMPSTER'S truth-prevailing tongue;</br>Hence, sweet-harmonious BEATTIE SUNG</br>His 'Minstrel-lays;'</br>Or tore, with noble ardour stung,</br>The Sceptic's bays.
"To lower Orders are assign'd,</br>The humbler ranks of Human-kind,</br>The rustic Bard, the lab'ring Hind,</br>The Artisan;</br>All chuse, as, various they're inclin'd,</br>The various man.

"When yellow waves the heavy grain,</br>The threat'ning Storm, some, strongly, rein;</br>Some teach to meliorate the plain,</br>With tillage-skill;</br>And some instruct the Shepherd-train,</br>Blythe o'er the hill.

"Some hint the Lover's harmless wile;</br>Some grace the Maiden's artless smile;</br>Some soothe the Lab'rer's weary toil,</br>For humble gains,</br>And make his cottage-scenes beguile</br>His cares and pains.
"Some, bounded to a district-space,</br>Explore at large Man's infant-race,</br>To mark the embryotic trace,</br>Of rustic Bard;</br>And careful note each op'ning grace,</br>A guide and guard.
"Of these am I — COILA my name;</br>And this district as mine I claim,</br>Where once the Campbell's, chiefs of fame,</br>Held ruling pow'r:</br>I mark'd thy embryo-tuneful flame,</br>Thy natal hour.
"With future hope, I oft would gaze,</br>Fond, on thy little, early ways,</br>Thy rudely-caroll'd, chiming phrase,</br>In uncouth rhymes,</br>Fir'd at the simple, artless lays</br>Of other times.

"I saw thee seek the sounding shore,</br>Delighted with the dashing roar;</br>Or when the North his fleecy store</br>Drove thro' the sky,</br>I saw grim Nature's visage hoar,</br>Struck thy young eye.

"Or when the deep-green-mantl'd Earth,</br>Warm-cherish'd ev'ry floweret's birth,</br>And joy and music pouring forth,</br>In ev'ry grove,</br>I saw thee eye the gen'ral mirth</br>With boundless love.

"When ripen'd fields, and azure skies,</br>Call'd forth the Reaper's rustling noise,</br>I saw thee leave their ev'ning joys,</br>And lonely stalk,</br>To vent thy bosom's swelling rise,</br>In pensive walk.

"When youthful Love, warm-blushing, strong,</br>Keen-shivering shot thy nerves along,</br>Those accents, grateful to thy tongue,</br>Th' adored Name,</br>I taught thee how to pour in song,</br>To soothe thy flame.

"I saw thy pulse's maddening play,</br>Wild-send thee Pleasure's devious way,</br>Misled by Fancy's meteor-ray,</br>By Passion driven;</br>But yet the light that led astray,</br>Was light from Heaven.

"I taught thy manners-painting strains,</br>The loves, the ways of simple swains,</br>Till now, o'er all my wide domains,</br>Thy fame extends;</br>And some, the pride of Coila's plains,</br>Become thy friends.

"Thou canst not learn, nor I can show,</br>To paint with Thomson's landscape-glow;</br>Or wake the bosom-melting throe,</br>With Shenstone's art;</br>Or pour, with Gray, the moving flow,</br>Warm on the heart.
"Yet all beneath th' unrivall'd Rose,</br>The lowly Daisy sweetly blows;</br>Tho' large the forest's Monarch throws</br>His army shade,</br>Yet green the juicy Hawthorn grows,</br>Adown the glade.
"Then never murmur nor repine;</br>Strive in thy humble sphere to shine;</br>And trust me, not Potosi's mine,</br>Nor Kings regard,</br>Can give a bliss o'ermatching thine,</br>A rustic Bard.
"To give my counsels all in one,</br>Thy tuneful flame still careful fan;</br>Preserve the dignity of Man,</br>With Soul erect;</br>And trust, the UNIVERSAL PLAN</br>Will all protect.

"And wear thou this" — she solemn said,</br>And bound the Holly round my head:</br>The polish'd leaves, and berries red,</br>Did rustling play;</br>And, like a passing thought, she fled,</br>In light array.</br>
